messageBody:
Hi,

So I'm still not sure if you mean you want to Unit test or System
test, using the JUnit framework.

I'm going to show how I would Unit Test the code, using JUnit.....


The code as it stands, makes unit testing difficult because of the use
of Singletons, static methods and raw Corba or RMi objects. So I'm
going to refactor it somewhat to make it testable. Making it testable
usually makes the design more flexible, finer grained and loosely
coupled - all good things.

First step - move the property setting code into its own class - then
test it there instead of inside the main() method. This is because
the main() method has calls to a singleton and creates CORBA objects,
which I can't easily get around, as this code is inside the static
'main()' method. If this code lived inside an instance method of
Server, then I could inject a mock object for these.

So, here's the main method, with the MTT Host and UUID property
setting code moved into a new class. The new class's method also only
knows about normal Java classes (InetAddress) instead of being coupled
to the VestUUID class - this makes unit testing really easy!!!!


public static void main(String[] args) {
if (args.length >= 1) {
try {
// set the initial environment
AnotherServer.getInstance().setEnvironment();

Server obj = Server.getInstance();

_serverUUID = new VespUuid(args[0]);

InetAddress inetAddress = _serverUUID.getInetAddress();
SystemPropertyConfigurator.setMttHostProperty(inetAddress,
Server._serverUUID.getPort());

if (args.length >= 2) {
SystemPropertyConfigurator.setOrbUuidProperty(args[1]);
}
} catch (Exception e) {
// todo...
throw new RuntimeException(e);
}
}
}


Here's the new class......(as it currently stands)


import java.net.InetAddress;

public class SystemPropertyConfigurator {

static void setMttHostProperty(InetAddress inetAddress, String port) {
StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer(inetAddress.toString());
sb.delete(0, 1);
sb.append(":");
sb.append(port);

String sInetAddress = sb.toString();
System.setProperty(VespConfigParams.MTT_INSTANCE_HOST_PROPERTY,
sInetAddress);
}



static void setOrbUuidProperty(String uuid) {
System.setProperty(VespConfigParams.ORB_UUID_PROPERTY, uuid);
}

}




And now here's its unit test!!!!!!!!!!! (these run and pass in my eclipse)


import java.net.InetAddress;
import java.net.UnknownHostException;

import junit.framework.TestCase;

public class SystemPropertyConfiguratorTest extends TestCase {

public void testMttHostPropertySetWithoutFirstLetter() throws
UnknownHostException {
InetAddress address = InetAddress.getByName("localhost");

SystemPropertyConfigurator.setMttHostProperty(address, "8080");

String actualProperty =
System.getProperty(VespConfigParams.MTT_INSTANCE_HOST_PROPERTY);

String expectedProperty = "ocalhost/127.0.0.1:8080";

assertNotNull("Property not found!", actualProperty);
assertEquals("Wrong property value!", expectedProperty, actualProperty);
}


public void testOrbUuidPropertySet() {
SystemPropertyConfigurator.setOrbUuidProperty("a UUID!");

String actualProperty =
System.getProperty(VespConfigParams.ORB_UUID_PROPERTY);

assertNotNull("Property not found!", actualProperty);
assertEquals("Wrong property value!", "a UUID!", actualProperty);
}

}




Now, as things stand, I may decide to not unit test the 'main()'
method in Server class at all, as all its doing is calling others to
do things, I might rely upon the normal System and integeration tests
to test it. Or I may decide to refactor the Server class as well, to
allow me to make the main() method more testable (which will involve
similar techniques as I've shown here). The choice comes down as
always to one of time vs payback.

Hopefully this is enough to get you started in thinking baout how to
change your design slightly, to enable unit testing of the code,
without having to have real corba, networks, files, dbs, etc around.

Feel free to ask for more help...

Andrew

For it to run in the actul enviroment, it uses a wrapper .exe which
calls an xml file where all the server properties are listed in the
main method the location of .class files are specified which are
already compiled and put in the java\lib folder in the form of .jar.

Hi,

Not sure why your Java app does not use Java's corba ability (a good Java
ORB being http://www.jacorb org/ ), instead of JNI...

Anyway, onto your real question, how do I test the code that is dependant
upon the other servers?

As you are asking on the JUnit list I take it you mean Unit test?
Not System or Integration testing?

If so, then you will find unit testing much simpler and (imo) better, if
none of your unit tests need to access any file, network, database or UI.
This means they run very fast. Once you figure out how to do them, you
should be able to write lots of them , quickly too.

We could just give you some simple examples, but I tend to find it better
to show you how to unit test one of your classes that depend on corba or
some other system, by using one of your real classes. So, please post
(just one) class and we'll knock up a unit test for it.

Regards

Andrew

Hi Group
Greetings to all. These days I am writting test suit for a CORBA CRM. Let
me first introduce the system.

There is a central ORB server and many other servers which talk to each
other through vesp. ORB being the central one. Entire code base is in C++.
I have to test a new server introduced in the system which is written in
Java. This new server talks to the rest through JNI. As a matter of Fact
none of the servers can run independently, they neccesirily have to log
into the central kit and report to the the central ORB server. After
validation stuff the server starts working.

Even this new Java based server uses an executable file to work
(Jloader.exe written in c++)

This .exe loads various .dll files in the system and in its main method
calls the compiled .class files. This is the way how system functions.

My problem is that when I will write a JUnit test case in IDE (eclipse)
which would operate on the actual code which has 99% dependency and cannot
be tested isolated. Is there any way to test this server code while it is
working under the live system and the test suite running in the eclipse
IDE.

HELP !!!

Thanks
Avinash
